node.text:
WARNING: CALIFORNIA VOTERS - SAVE CALIFORNIA DEMOCRACY
. 
All California voters were mailed a ballot on the Gavin Newsom Recall Election. It’s important that you vote NO. 
A NO Vote is against the recall, NOT the governor. Newsom will remain governor.
.
Why trade pot friendly for ANTI-DRUG?  All Drugs! Including cannabis.
I think that Newsom has done a very good job during these trying times.  
He followed science regarding the pandemic and helped families in need.
This fellow has empathy.
 .
Don’t let the ultra-conservatives in the Republican party steal this election from us. If enough of us don’t vote they will.
.
All you have to do is mail in your ballot NOW! After checking the NO box.
It only takes a moment and it will determine California policy for the next two years. If you don’t think it’s important, vote NO as a favor to me. 
Check the NO Box and Drop the ballot in the mail or a secure ballot drop box before Sept. 14th.  I understand that this post might ruffle some feathers. Which is fine. There is nothing wrong with a robust, even controversial conversation. But I politely ask you to be civil in your comments. 
Thank you!

node.text:
What is a Stigma?
.
Excerpt from my upcoming Cannabis Grower’s Handbook 
[Pre-Order it in my link tree]
.
“Each female flower has two stigmas that protrude from a single ovule; they are “fuzzy” (hirsute), about ¼ to ½ inch long, usually white, but sometimes yellowish, or pink to red and, rarely, lavender to purple. Stigmas are the pollen catchers. Some writers identify stigmas as pistils, and this is incorrect. The pistil is all of the reproductive female flower parts. The pistil consists of two stigmas and an ovule (prospective seed). The term is misused in many books and seed catalogs that describe a single flower as having two pistils.” @melfrank420 
.
Photo by the wonderful @zoom_gardens
.
.
.
#GROWYOUROWN 💪🏼 #cannabis #cannabiscommunity #cannabisculture #edrosenthal #cannabisgrowershandbook

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Ed Rosenthal | Guru of Ganja on August 27, 2021 tagging @edrosenthal420, @christianpetke, @picture_fotografie, @thehumboldtseedcompany, and @pinchandpull1. May be an image of text that says 'CANNABIS BREEDING'.

node.text:
Cannabis Breeding - Photo by @picture_fotografie 
.
“Seasoned growers and breeders know all too well the horrible feeling of loving and losing a particular cannabis varietal. Cultural changes, disease, legal challenges, and a host of other factors have led to the loss of many special and much-loved cultivars. Seed production is a great way for backyard gardeners to preserve and stabilize their favorite varietals and save them for future seasons and future generations.
.
The process is the same whether setting up a breeding project with seeds found in a bag of herb or creating a new varietal with seeds ordered online. Start by germinating as many seeds as possible. 
Segregating males from females is key. Select a choice male with the desired characteristics and be sure to keep him separated from the female garden. He can be used to pollinate a lower branch of each female plant during the second to fourth week of flowering, depending on specific varietals. “
Excerpt from my new book Cannabis Grower’s Handbook by @thehumboldtseedcompany 
.
I recently ran into an interesting technical solution for that process. @pinchandpull1 has developed an inexpensive system to pollinate individual branches of female plants [swipe to check it out - I used Pinch and Pull’s Bag on a female Ed Rosenthal Super Bud and some Blue Dream pollen]. This allows you to safely pollinate a specific branch of one female. You can also pollinate one mother plant with various males at the same time [each in their individual bag]. This could create a whole new system of trade. Imagine you can buy pre pollinated bags with select prize male pollen. 
What are your thoughts?
.
.
.
#GROWYOUROWN 💪🏼 #cannabis #cannabiscommunity #cannabisculture #edrosenthal #cannabisgrowershandbook

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Ed Rosenthal | Guru of Ganja on August 25, 2021. May be a closeup.

node.text:
This variety will always have a special place my heart - Thank you @sensiseeds.official 
.
Ed Rosenthal Super Bud Regular is notable for perfectly balancing both sativa and indica genetics (it is a 50% split of each). This results in a plant that produces extremely large harvests, with a fairly rapid flowering time. The scent is of a pure sativa; pineapple-tinged, spicy and sweet. Expect a high that’s both calming and uplifting, with a sense of euphoria.
.
Ed Rosenthal Super Bud Regular cannabis combines genetics from around the world; Africa, Central America and South East Asia, to name a few; and some of the sativa parentage is top secret.Ed Rosenthal Super Bud Regular has a relatively swift flowering time of 55 to 65 days. When grown inside, the plants are usually compact, and reach around 3 to 5 feet in height on average. Outdoors, they’re likely to grow much taller; to heights of around 9 feet.
.
As the strain is a 50/50 split of indica and sativa, appearances can vary from plant to plant. Some are more sativa in nature, with multiple stems and large, spiraling calyxes. Others look more ‘indica’, with thick central stems and fuzzy hairs on the ends of the buds. Either way, they’re capable of producing formidable yields. Ed Rosenthal Super Bud Regular thrives best in Mediterranean climates, with plenty of exposure to warmth and sun. Alternatively, the plants can be grown indoors all year around, in any location around the world. The strain responds well to both lollipopping and supercropping.
.
The 50/50 split of indica and sativa is reflected in the high, which offers the classically indica ‘body-stone’, combined with the uplifting, happy qualities of a sativa. Users often praise the unique blend of relaxation and mental alertness that this strain provides. The plants have an exotic aroma; a mix of earthiness and fruitiness that reveals its sativa / indica heritage. The overall scent is reminiscent of pineapple, with other notes of citrus coming through.
.
Photo by @christianpetke
.
.
.
#GROWYOUROWN 💪🏼 #cannabis #cannabiscommunity #cannabisculture #edrosenthal #cannabisgrowershandbook

node.text:
I posted about water yesterday and just saw this post from @mendodopeboys - this is a very serious topic and we really need to start thinking about the way we treat our home.
.
“How’s everyone’s year going with this drought? We have definitely noticed that the ground out here has literally been sucked dry! Keeping the plants happy with enough water has been harder than ever. Even the vegetable garden is a struggle this season, I’ve had to let a majority of them just die off because we are just using too much water for the restrictions. We have heard it numerous times over the years that California one day would turn into a dessert land and if it keeps going at this rate it’s seems very true. Certain areas and communities are going through some very hard times right now, not even flushing toilets it is that bad. 
Whats your thoughts?”
.
.
.
#GROWYOUROWN 💪🏼 #cannabis #cannabiscommunity #cannabisculture #edrosenthal #cannabisgrowershandbook

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Ed Rosenthal | Guru of Ganja on August 23, 2021. May be a closeup of nature.

node.text:
Water is truly the elixir of life! 
.
Here is another teaser from my upcoming book Cannabis Grower's Handbook. I am incredibly proud of our team amazing team of experts that contributed to this book! Photo by @cannaforniadreamin637 
.
Water - Revised by Rosa Raudales, PhD
.
Not all water is created equal; the chemistry of water differs by source. Three key measures of water chemistry that affect plants are alkalinity, pH, and the concentration of dissolved minerals. Mineral content is reported as the concentration of individual elements such as calcium and sodium or total salts. The total concentration of salts is reported as electrical conductivity (EC, measured in millisiemens per centimeter, or mS/cm) or total dissolved salts (TDS, measured in ppm).
.
Alkalinity is the ability of the water to buffer acids. When water contains components that behave similar to limestone such as carbonates (H2CO3), or bicarbonates (HCO), then water pH is not affected as much by the addition of acidic substances such as a water-soluble fertilizer with high ammonium or urea. Water alkalinity reacts with acids to prevent dramatic changes in pH. Water with low or zero alkalinity will result in fast and dramatic drops of pH because there is nothing in the water to react with or buffer the acid in the solution.
.
Water with no dissolved minerals and no alkalinity is considered “pure water” or “soft water.” The electrical conductivity and alkalinity of pure water are zero. The benefit of this water is that it is a clean slate to develop a nutrient program. The grower has full control; it is easy to add elements. The disadvantage is that with no alkalinity, there is no buffering ability, so the pH fluctuates.
.
.
.
#GROWYOUROWN 💪🏼 #cannabis #cannabiscommunity #cannabisculture #edrosenthal #cannabisgrowershandbook

node.text:
When and how to harvest? One question I get asked over and over again. So we dedicated a whole chapter in the Cannbais Grower's Handbook to it. Below is a part of the introduction
.
"Harvesting, drying, curing, and storing are incredibly important processes to growers. Each contributes to the final quality of the flowers and the end-use products processed from them. A good crop followed by poor post-harvest practices is as disastrous as crop failure. 
.
Even a small harvest requires a little bit of labor. Processing a large one adds complexity and requires planning. Determining when to cut the crop, whether to cut whole plants or to judge each bud for its ripeness, when to trim, how and where to dry and cure the buds for use or processing, and how to preserve the aroma and taste by retaining the terpenes and essential oils are important decisions for any harvest.
.
Growers usually plan their gardens in great detail by setting timetables and cultivation parameters for their plants and bringing the plants to the peak of maturity. However, they often spend a lot less time planning the harvest. Even large commercial operations are sometimes far behind in harvest and post-harvest operations. These final tasks need the most thought; they are the ones most likely to be improperly executed—but they needn’t be. With proper preparation the process can flow seamlessly."
. 
Photo taken by @phenofocus in my next book Cannabis Grower's Handbook

.
.
.
#GROWYOUROWN 💪🏼 #cannabis #cannabiscommunity #cannabisculture #edrosenthal #cannabisgrowershandbook

node.text:
Someone asked me yesterday what those spikes looking trichomes are. So I figured I post another small excerpt from my upcoming book Cannabis Grower's Handbook. The images show you 3 different types. Can you figure out what's what?
.
Photo by @picture_fotografie
.
Different Types of Trichomes
.
Bulbous Trichome
Bulbous trichomes have no stalk and are much smaller than the other trichomes. They appear mostly on leaves rather than in the bud area, especially during vegetative growth, and contain cannabinoids.
.
Cystolith Trichomes [non glandular]
These trichomes do not contain cannabinoids. They grow on the bottom of the leaves to deter pests.
.
Sessile Stalked Capitate Trichome
These trichomes appear during the vegetative growth stage and produce only small amounts of cannabinoids.
.
Stalked Capitate Glandular Trichomes
These trichomes are the most abundant and contain the desired cannabinoids, terpenoids, and flavonoids that growers seek.
.
.
.
#GROWYOUROWN 💪🏼 #cannabis #cannabiscommunity #cannabisculture #edrosenthal #cannabisgrowershandbook
